Policy: Law No. 982-XIV on access to information.
Policy_Content: This Law regulates the following issues: (a) relations between providers of information and natural and/or legal persons in the process of the realization of their constitutional right of access to information; (b) principles, terms and conditions, and also methods of access to information; and (c) duties of the providers of the official information. This Law guarantees access to any person to the official information. Providers of the official information shall have the duty to: (a) timely inform citizens of the issues of public interest; (b) ensure free access to information; (c) immediately inform the population on issues that can prevent or reduce risks of any damage, prevent spreading of unreliable information or reduce its negative consequences, and on issues of public interest.

Policy: Strategy and National Action Plan for Biodiversity
Policy_Content: The objectives of this Strategy and Action Plan  for biodiversity conservation in Guinea-Bissau can be summarized as follows: Maintain biodiversity through the establishment of a network of protected areas to conserve ecosystems in its various components; Restore degraded ecosystems; Establish priorities in the use and conservation of species according to their economic importance and/or their conservation; Develop plans and integrated programmes for the conservation and development, especially in the sectors whose development is based on the use of biological diversity. The Strategy and Action Plan deal with several aspect of the natural resources sustainable use and protection. The exploitation of water resources is carried out mainly through wells. Considering the socio-economic importance, considerable effort was made by the Government of Guinea-Bissau, regarding the definition of policies and strategies for the sustainable development of resources in certain sectors, especially when it comes to those that focus on specific natural renewable resources.

Policy: Directive 2000/14/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council on the approximation of the laws of the Member States relating to the noise emission in the environment by equipment for use outdoors.
Policy_Content: The aim of this Directive is the harmonization of the laws of the Member States relating to noise emission standards, conformity assessment procedures, marking, technical documentation and collection of data concerning the noise emission in the environment of equipment for use outdoors. The Directive applies to equipment for use outdoors listed out in articles 12 and 13 and defined in Annex I. Such equipment shall not be placed on the market or put into service until the manufacturer ensures that: (1) the equipment satisfies the requirements concerning the noise emission in the environment of this Directive; (2) the conformity assessment procedures referred to in article 14 have been completed; (3) the equipment bears CE marking. Article 9 refers to the measures to be undertaken by Member States in respect of equipment that does not fulfill the requirements hereby established. Article 14 describes the conformity procedure above-mentioned. Article 16 concerns the collection of noise data. The following Annexes are attached: (I) Definitions of equipment; (II) EC Declaration of conformity; (III) Methods of measurements of airborne noise emitted by equipment for use outdoors; (IV) Models of the CE marking of conformity and of the indication of the guaranteed sound power level; (V) Internal control of production; (VI) Internal control of production with assessment of technical documentation and periodical checking; (VII) Unit verification; (VIII) Full quality assurance; (IX) Minimum criteria to be taken into account by Member States for the notification of bodies; (X) Model of conformity certificate.

Policy: Law No. 78 “On the prevention, detection and punishment of corruption.”
Policy_Content: This Law establishes measures for the prevention, detection and punishment of corruption and applies to the following persons: (a) who exercise a public function, regardless of the way in which they have been invested, within public authorities or public institutions; (b) who perform, permanently or temporarily, according to the acting legislation, a function or a task, to the extent that they participate in or can influence decisions, within public services, autonomous corporations, companies, national companies, cooperative units or other economic agents; (c) who exercise control duties, according to the acting legislation; (d) who provide specialized assistance to the units referred to in lit. (a) and (b), in so far as they participate in decision-making or are able to influence it; (e) who, regardless of their capacity, carry out, control or provide specialized assistance, in so far as they participate in decision-making or are able to influence it, in respect of: transactions involving the movement of capital, banking, foreign exchange or credit transactions, investment transactions, on stock exchanges, in insurance, in mutual funds or concerning bank accounts and those assimilated to them, domestic and international commercial transactions; (f) who hold a leading position in a political party or group, in a trade union, in an employers' organization or in a non-profit-making association or foundation; (g) other natural persons than those referred to in item (a) of this Article who are not members of a political party or group, or who are not members of a trade union, employers' organization or a non-profit-making association or foundation. The acts of bribery or influence peddling committed by a person who: (a) holds public office; (b) is a judge or prosecutor; (c) is a criminal investigation body or has the powers of ascertaining or sanctioning contraventions; (d) is one of the persons referred to in Article 293 of the Criminal Code shall be punished by the penalty referred to in Article 289 or 291 of the Criminal Code, the limits of which shall be increased by one third. The following offences shall be punishable by imprisonment for a term of three to ten years and disqualification from exercising certain rights, if committed with the aim of obtaining for oneself or for another person money, property or other undue advantage: (a) the intentional determination of a lower value, in relation to the real commercial value, of goods belonging to economic operators in which the State or a local public administration authority is a shareholder, committed in the context of privatization or foreclosure action, judicial reorganization or liquidation or in the course of a commercial operation, or of goods belonging to the public authority or public institutions; (b) the award of grants in breach of the law or the failure to ensure, in accordance with the law, that the purpose for which the grants are awarded is complied with; and (c) the use of grants for purposes other than those for which they were awarded and the use for other purposes of loans guaranteed by public funds or to be repaid from public funds. This Law consists of V Chapter divided into 33 Articles. Chapter I lays down general provisions. Chapter II establishes special rules of conduct concerning certain categories of persons in order to prevent corruption. Chapter III classifies corruption offences. Chapter IV establishes procedural provisions. Chapter V lays down final provisions.
Subject: General
Geographical_area: Black Sea, Eastern Europe, Europe, EUROPE AND CENTRAL ASIA, European Union Countries
Entry into force notes: This Law enters into force on the date of its official publication.

Policy: Law No. VIII-1649 “On Special Investigation Services.”
Policy_Content: This Law establishes the purpose of the Special Investigation Service of the Republic of Lithuania, the legal bases, tasks and functions of the activity, the organization and financing of the Service, the methods of control over the activities and the rights and duties of officials. The Special Investigation Service of the Republic of Lithuania is a state law enforcement institution accountable to the President of the Republic and the Seimas (Parliament), which prepares and implements corruption prevention measures, detects and investigates crimes involving corruption. The Special Investigation Service follows the Constitution of the Republic of Lithuania, the laws of the Republic of Lithuania, international treaties of the Republic of Lithuania, the Statute of the Office and other legal acts. The Statute of the Special Investigation Service shall be approved by the Seimas (Parliament) of the Republic of Lithuania by law. The Government of the Republic of Lithuania, ministries and other state or municipal institutions and establishments must, at the request of the Special Investigation Service, submit to it within 5 working days legal acts adopted but not published in the Official Gazette. State or municipal institutions and establishments must enable the Special Investigation Service to use the data of state registers, cadastres, classifications and other data banks of state institutions, establishments and enterprises free of charge and without hindrance, and other enterprises, establishments, organizations and natural persons under contracts. The Special Investigation Service protects and defends the individual, society and the state from corruption, and carries out the prevention and detection of corruption. Special Investigation Service shall perform the following functions: (a) carry out operational activities in order to detect and prevent crimes that manifest corruption; (b) conduct a preliminary investigation; (c) cooperate with other law enforcement institutions in accordance with the procedure established by legal acts; (d) collect, store, analyze and summarize information on corruption and related social and economic phenomena; (e) prepare and implement corruption prevention and other measures on the basis of available information; (f) implement crime control and prevention programs with other law enforcement institutions; and (g) at least twice a year provide written information on the results of its activities and submit proposals regarding the improvement of the activities of the Service to the President of the Republic and the Speaker of the Seimas (Parliament).
Subject: General
Geographical_area: Europe, EUROPE AND CENTRAL ASIA, European Union Countries, Northern Europe

This Decree sets forth rules and regulations of determining plots of land for industries, residences, cultural structure, roads, intersections, green areas and other construction areas, considering the impacts of earthquakes, landslides, floods and other natural and man-made disasters and in addition, principles of usage of these areas. Methods for land zoning shall be in two ways in accordance with the principles of environmental protection, efficient use of the resources, historical and cultural heritage and population, such as: zoning throughout the entire territory and zoning throughout the city and other settlements.
Subject: Land & soil
Geographical_area: Asia, Caspian Sea, CIS (Commonwealth of Independent States), EUROPE AND CENTRAL ASIA, Landlocked Developing Countries, Western Asia
Entry into force notes: This Decree enters into force upon signature.

Policy: Ministerial Decree No. 79 on approval of rules regarding conservation, recovery and use of lands affected by radioactive and chemical contamination.
Policy_Content: This Decree aims at conservation and recovery of lands affected by radioactive and chemical contamination which pose a threat to human health and do not meet the sanitary requirements, by withdrawing them from economic circulation and transfer them to the State Reserve Fund for restoration. This Decree states that measures shall be taken against hazardous chemicals used in plant protection and mineral fertilizers in agricultural land as well as industrial and domestic waste water and waste. This Decree determines the methods of conservation and recovery operations that depend on contamination level of soil, depth of contamination, soil classification, mineralogy and geographical features of environment.

Policy: Ministerial Decree No. 79 on approval of rules regarding permit for process engineering and agricultural activities in lands affected by exogenous processes.
Policy_Content: By this Decree, the rules were approved regarding permit for process engineering and agricultural activities in lands affected by landslide, flood, erosion, wind erosion, land subsidence, abrasion and volcanic mud as well as in wetlands. This Decree states that the State Committee of Geology and Mineral Resources shall be the authorized body for assessment of exposure and monitoring of exogenous geological processes and shall take measures against them. This Decree underlines that utilization of lands affected by exogenous geological processes for any purpose without the consent of the central executive bodies is prohibited.

Policy: Ministerial Decree No. 78 on approval of the Charter for conservation of state forest fund and forest restoration.
Policy_Content: This Decree sets forth principles and procedures of the protection of forests and forest restoration. This Decree states that protection of forests is a system consists of organizational, legal and other measures to ensure efficient use of forest fund and to protect forests from fire, illegal logging, pollution, deforestation, environmental damage, pests, diseases and other negative impacts. The forest protection measures are indicated as (a) carrying out state control, (b) preventing infringement of the established order of forests, (c) bringing responsible legal and real persons to justice in the manner specified in the legislation, (d) limiting, suspending or prohibiting the activities of enterprises causing damage to forest fund, and (e) implementing other measures stipulated by the legislation. The purpose of forest restoration is the timely forest restoration on forest land not covered with vegetation, improvement of forests’ composition, increasing productivity and ensuring the efficient use of lands of forest fund. This Decree sets forth fundamental duties of the Ministry of Ecology and Natural Resources in the field of forest restoration as (i) registration of forest restoration works, (ii) determining the size, location, duration and methods of forest restoration in separate categories of land, (iii) providing the selection of forest tree species and forestry seeds, (iv) carrying out reforestation activities by planting high yield, protective and valuable trees, (v) taking measures for increasing the productivity of forest fund and for protecting forests from erosion, (vi) suspending or limiting the activities of forest users in case of affecting the forest development adversely, and (vii) monitoring the activities related to the restoration and development of forests.
Subject: Forestry

Policy: Agriculture Law.

The Law applies to all agricultural enterprises and lands including alpine regions and pastures as well as to animal farms and to productive gardening. The text consists of 37 articles divided into 9 Parts as follows: General provisions (I); Competent authorities (II); Production and marketing (III); Livestock farming (IV); Contributions and subsidies (V); Vocational training and farm advising (VI); Costs and fees (VII); Contracts of employment (VIII); Final provisions (IX).

Policy: Regional Law No. 179-OZ “On plenary powers of state bodies and local self-government in the sphere of land relations.
Policy_Content: The scope of this Regional Law shall be delimitation of plenary powers between legislative and executive state bodies, and local self-government in the sphere of land relations. Legislative Assembly shall have the following competence: (a) adoption of legislation related to land relations; (b) classification of land as federal, regional and municipal property; (c) validation of minimum and maximum land plot dimensions pertaining to public ownership that can be allotted to citizens for agricultural purposes, and that can be allotted free of charge to citizens for other purposes; and (d) validation of the modalities of bail-out of land.  The Governor shall have the following competence: (a) bail-out of land for public needs; (c) transfer of land from one category to another; and (d) expropriation of land. Regional Government shall have the following competence: (a) zoning of land by natural and agricultural zones; (b) land survey, mapping and state land cadastre; and (c) establishment of standard land cost.

It shall be applicable to cargo vessels transporting oil, chemicals and gases, and to passenger vessels transporting hazardous or polluting solid or liquid cargo, or hazardous packages. Vessel operator shall communicate the aforesaid information to harbor traffic control center.

Policy: Regional Decree No. 295 validating the Regulation on state nature reserve of regional significance “Ordynsky”.
Policy_Content: State nature reserve of regional significance “Ordynsky” shall be considered biological (zoological) reserve constituted with a view of conservation and reproduction of precious, rare and endangered wild fauna species and natural habitats thereof. Protected natural area of regional significance shall be organized for an unlimited period of time for the following purposes: (a) conservation of natural complexes and objects of forest steppe area of Western Siberia in a natural state; (b) conservation, reproduction and restoration of natural resources, enrichment of adjoining land areas used for economic activities; (c) protection of mating and reproduction grounds of elk, roe deer, hares, upland game, colonies of badger and other wild fauna species; (d) protection of habitats of rare and endangered wild fauna and wild flora species; (e) maintaining overall ecological balance and stable functioning of ecosystem; and (f) ensuring environmental education of the population. The following activities shall be prohibited on the territory of state nature reserve: (a) commercial, sport, artisanal hunting and other form of wildlife management; (b) all types of fisheries except for artisanal and sport fishing by local residents; (c) all types of felling except for sanitary felling; (d) destruction of forest outliers by any economic activity; (e) harvesting and procurement of non-timber forest products, except for procurement and collection of twigs for fodder and harvesting of spruce and other coniferous tree species for New Year holidays); (f) procurement of edible non-timber products and medicinal plants except for procurement thereof by citizens for individual personal needs); (g) procurement of soft resin; (h) cultivation of forest fruit bearing, ornamental and medicinal plant species; (i) use of forests for wood processing; (j) application and storage of toxic chemicals, mineral fertilizers and nutrients; (k) haymaking, grazing and passage of cattle outside specially allotted areas; (l) destruction or removal from natural environment of endangered plant species and mushrooms; (m) ploughing up of the territory; (n) destruction of nidifugous burrows, except for harmful animals; (o) devastation of nests and collection of eggs (except for crows); (p) drainage and irrigation, exploration of subsoil and mining; (q) burning of vegetation; (r) blasting operations; (s) water logging, construction of water reservoirs and other artificial waterbodies, and construction of waterworks; (t) allotment of land plots for construction, collective gardening and horticulture; (u) release and acclimatization of alien species; (u) zoological, botanical, mineralogical and paleontological collections; (v) recreational activities; (w) destruction or damaging of barriers, boards and other information displays and indication signs; (x) washing vehicles in water protection areas and movement of motor vehicles outside roads of common access; (y) stay with firearms, pneumatic and throwing weapons; and (z) stay with unleashed dogs outside residential areas, sharpening and training of hunting dogs.
Subject: Environment gen., Wild species & ecosystems
Keyword: Protected area,Ecosystem preservation,Protection of habitats,Education,Management/conservation,Wild fauna,Wild flora,Birds,Endangered species,Game,Protection of species

Policy: Environmental Audit, Assessment and Review Regulations, 2000 (L.N. No. 31 of 2000).
Policy_Content: These Regulations set out procedures for the proper preparation of environmental audit reports for existing and proposed projects that may result in the issuing of a environmental compliance certificate. The Swaziland Environment Authority shall: (a) identify and maintain a list of undertakings which cause concern to the Authority or to the public because of their impact on the environment and shall publish the list of these undertakings in its annual report; (b) require an operator of an identified or listed undertaking to submit an EA report and a CMP to the Authority and that operator shall submit to the Authority the EA report and the CMP within six (6) months after notification to do so. The certificate states that a proposed project under consideration is not likely to cause unacceptable environmental impacts and that the proponent shall manage the construction and operation of the project in accordance with an approved comprehensive mitigation plan. "Comprehensive mitigation plan" means a document containing a description of the mitigation measures to be implemented that would prevent, reduce or otherwise manage the environmental impacts of a project and done according to the reporting requirements of the Second Schedule. The Authority shall annually identify and maintain a list of projects which cause concern to the Authority, because of their impact on the environment and shall publish the list of such projects in its annual report. An operator of an identified or listed project is required to submit an environmental audit report and a comprehensive mitigation plan.

Policy: Ministerial Decree No. 373 validating the Regulation of on the state registration of hazardous impact on the atmospheric air and the sources thereof.
Policy_Content: This Ministerial Decree establishes the modalities of the state registration of hazardous impact on the atmospheric air and the sources thereof. The main task of the state registration shall be to obtain information on quantity and composition of the emissions of pollutants to the atmosphere, types and amounts of hazardous impact on the atmospheric air and sources thereof. The state registration shall be carried out by the authorized state environmental institution. Legal persons owning the sources of emissions and also quantity and composition of pollutants, types and amount of negative impact upon the atmospheric air. The authorized state environmental institution shall carry out: (a) registration of the organizations subject to the state registration; (b) keeping databases of the organizations subject to the state registration and of quantity and compositions of the emissions of pollutants; and (c) inspection of primary registration of the emissions by the organizations.

Policy: Regulation No. 29 of State Committee on Land Resources regarding conservation of degraded agricultural land.
Policy_Content: This Regulation establishes that conservation of degraded agricultural land means temporary putting out of use thereof for the period of five years for the purpose of soil rehabilitation. It establishes basic principles for identification of degraded agricultural land, the modalities of exposure thereof and provisions for soil improvement and rehabilitation. In the process of identification of degraded agricultural land basic unit of degraded land shall be taken minimum irrigated plot of land (for irrigated land) and minimum plot of land with established boundaries (for non-irrigated land). Grounds for classification of agricultural land as degraded shall be: (a) reduction of crop yield by 20 percent in the last three years; (b) irregularity of the state of surface area (rough land cover, malfunctioning irrigation system, unsatisfactory land reclamation); and (c) request of landlords and land tenants specifying the causes of land degradation).
Subject: Land & soil

Policy: Law No.1699-II of 200 on land use planning and building.

The document consists of VII Secs. that contain 33 Arts. Section I (arts. 1-4) lays down general provisions. Section II (Arts. 5-9) regards land use planning at the national and at the regional levels. Section III (Arts. 10-19) regards land use planning at the local level. Section IV (Arts. 20-30) regards regulation of land use planning, building and other uses of the territories. Section V (Arts. 31-32) regards state control over land use planning, building and other uses of the territories, and establishes liability for the infringement of the legislation in the aforesaid sphere. Section VI (art. 33) regards international cooperation in the sphere of land use planning and building. Section VII lays down final provisions.

Policy: Council Regulation (EC) No. 814/2000 on information measures relating to the common agricultural policy.
Policy_Content: The aim pursued by this Regulation is to ensure a consistent, objective and comprehensive information and communication strategy with regard to the common agricultural policy. The Community therefore may finance information measures relating to the common agricultural policy with a view to: (a) helping, on the one hand, to explain and, on the other hand, to implement and develop that policy, (b) promoting the European model of agriculture and helping people understand it, (c) informing farmers and other parties active in rural areas, (d) raising public awareness of the issues and objectives of that policy. Those measures may include not only activities implemented at the Commission’s initiative, but also annual work programmes presented by farmers' or rural development organizations, consumers' associations and environmental protection associations.
Subject: Agricultural & rural development

Policy: Law No. 11.463 on Genetically Modified Organisms (GMO).
Policy_Content: This Law, composed of three articles, rules on Genetically Modified Organisms (GMO). In particular, it requires that all activities using GMOs, including research, testing and pilot actions, shall attain to the relevant Federal Law.
Subject: Environment gen., Cultivated plants

Policy: Presidential Decree No. UP-86 “On development and support of enterprises for procurement, processing and trade of agricultural commodities”.
Policy_Content: The President, for the purpose of development and support of enterprises for procurement, processing and trade of agricultural commodities, decrees as follows: (a) local state administration shall organize peasant cooperatives for procurement, supply and trade of agricultural commodities; and (b) to enforce veterinary, sanitary and technological requirements in the process of procurement, processing and trade of agricultural commodities. The Government shall ensure state purchase by public sector entities of foodstuffs from national producers through tenders.
Subject: Agricultural & rural development

Policy: Regional Law No. 393-OD “On safety of the population and environmental protection in the process of development of oil and gas deposits containing sulphuretted hydrogen.
Policy_Content: This Regional Law shall regulate exploration, prospecting, mining, extraction, transportation and processing of crude hydrocarbons containing sulphuretted hydrogen with a view of protection of the population and environment against risks of hazardous impact. It has as its scope to ensure the right of citizens to favourable environment and living conditions in the periods and in the areas of prospecting, exploration and mining of deposits of crude hydrocarbons. This Regional Law shall regulate licensing of the aforesaid activities related to crude hydrocarbons. Prospecting, exploration and mining of deposits of crude hydrocarbons are classified as extremely hazardous economic activities and as such shall be subject to constant environmental monitoring.
Subject: Environment gen., Mineral resources
Geographical_area: Arctic, ASIA AND THE PACIFIC, Black Sea, Caspian Sea, CIS (Commonwealth of Independent States), Eastern Europe, Europe, EUROPE AND CENTRAL ASIA, North Pacific, North-West Pacific

Policy: Ministerial Decree No. 326 regarding licensing of some types of activity.
Policy_Content: The Government decrees to validate the list of the Federal Executive Bodies authorized to issue licenses and the list of activities subject to licensing. The Federal Tax Service is authorized to license production, storage, delivery, import/export of ethyl alcohol, spirits and spirit-containing products for alimentary use, production and wholesale trade of tobacco products. The Ministry of Natural Resources is authorized to license well sinking and exploitation of waterworks. The Ministry of Agricultural Products is authorize to licence stockbreeding, veterinary activity, control and management of pesticides and plant variety. The Federal Committee on Land resources is authorized to license geodetic and cartographic activity for the purpose of land survey. The Federal Committee of Ecology is authorized to licence the obligatory certification and testing centres. The Federal Construction Committee is authorized to licence the projecting of centralized water supply and drainage systems. The Federal Hydrometeorological Committee is authorized to licence oceanographical projects and hydro-meteorological activity. The Russian Cartographic Service is authorized to licence geodetic and cartographic activity. The Federal Technological Survey is authorized to licence the production of well sinking and boring equipment. The Federal Bread Inspection is authorized to licence processing of grain and cereals, bread, bakery and macaroni food production.

Policy: Order of the Ministry of Natural Resources validating the Regulation on the federal state institution national park “Alkhanay”.
Policy_Content: This Regulation establishes that the location of the national park “Alkhanay” shall be Buryat autonomous region of the Russian Federation. National park “Alkhanay” shall perform the following tasks: (a) conservation of natural complexes, unique and reference natural sites and objects; (b) conservation of historical and cultural heritage; (c) environmental education of the population; (d) promotion of regulated tourism and recreation; (e) development and introduction of scientific methods of nature protection and environmental education; (f) implementation of state environmental monitoring; (g) protection and restoration of forest fund, reforestation and protection of biological diversity; and (h) restoration of disturbed natural and historical-cultural complexes and objects. On the territory of the national park, shall be prohibited any activity that can damage natural complexes and objects of flora and fauna, cultural and historical objects and which contradicts the purposes and tasks of the national park, including: (a) exploration and mining; (b) disturbance of the soil cover and geological outcrops; (c) activities entailing changes in the hydrological regime; (d) allotment of land parcels for horticulture and smallholding; (e) construction of main roads, pipelines, power transmission lines and other communications, as well as construction and operation of economic and residential facilities, not related to the functioning of the national park; (f) clear cutting and thinning operations; (g) procurement of soft resin; (h) commercial, sports and artisanal hunting, commercial fisheries; (i) industrial procurement of wild-growing plants; (j) disturbance of natural habitats of wild fauna and wild flora species; (k) biological collections, except for research purposes, envisaged by thematic and research plans of the Institution; (l) introduction of living organisms in order to acclimatize them; (m) passage and grazing of domestic animals; (n) organization of mass sports and entertainment events, organization of tourist camps and making bonfires outside the specially designated places for such purpose; (o) waste disposal of domestic and non-domestic waste, untreated effluent waste water; and (p) destruction and damage of posts, barriers, stands, boundary poles and other information signs, developed ecological paths and recreation areas, buildings on the territory of the national park, as well as property of the Institution, inscriptions and signs on boulders, outcrops and historical and cultural objects.
Subject: Forestry, Wild species & ecosystems
Geographical_area: Arctic, ASIA AND THE PACIFIC, Black Sea, Caspian Sea, CIS (Commonwealth of Independent States), Eastern Europe, Europe, EUROPE AND CENTRAL ASIA, North Pacific, North-West Pacific

Policy: Decree of the Minister of Natural Resources No. 210 of 2000 relative the measurement, marking and registration of timber.
Policy_Content: The holder of a concession or permit in the sense of the Forestry Management Act 1992 shall after felling mark each trunk or felled tree according to instructions of Chief of National Forestry Management. Each log shall be labelled with a unique number and shall be measured according to instructions. The tree numbers, the registration numbers and label numbers shall be registered at the initiative of the holder of a concession or permit in the Logging Register as established by the Act.

Policy: Decree of the Minister of Natural Resources No. 228 of 2000 implementing section 46 of the Forestry Management Act 1992 relative to the Forestry Register.

Each person who commercially transports or trades in timber products shall be registered in the Forestry Register that shall be kept by the Chief National Forestry Management. Policy: Ministerial Decree No. 316 of 2000 regarding validation of the Regulation on carrying out state cadastre valuation of land.
Policy_Content: The Government, for the purpose of putting into order state cadastre valuation of land on the territory of the Russian Federation, decrees to validate the Regulation. This Regulation determines the modalities of carrying out state cadastre valuation of land as regards all the categories of land on the territory of the Russian Federation for the purpose of taxation and other purposes established by law. State Committee on Land Policy, its territorial branches and its subordinate enterprises and organizations carry out state cadastre valuation of land. State cadastre valuation of land is carried out for determination of cadastre value of the plots of land of various designation. State cadastre valuation of land is based upon classification of land in accordance with its designation and functional use. State cadastre valuation of land is carried out with the use of data of Land cadastre, Urban cadastre, Forest cadastre, Water cadastre and other cadastres. The results of state cadastre valuation of land are registered in the state land cadastre. The disputes originating from state cadastre valuation of land are settled in legal form.

Policy: Regional Act No. 25 encouraging the use of organic fertilizers to protect the quality of agricultural lands.
Policy_Content: The Emilia-Romagna Region encourages the use of organic material in agricultural activities in order to guarantee the quality of agricultural lands and prevent soil degradation and desertification. For this purpose, the regional authority promotes the creation of a monitoring system intended for the assessment of soil conditions. The Region shall grant subsidies, giving particular priority to the purchase of organic material and related equipment and devices (art. 3). The agricultural enterprises defined by article 4 may participate to this financial scheme. Furthermore, the Region provides for the adoption of a valuation system concerning soil conditions and intended to verify the effects of cultivation practices performed. Surveys and studies shall be carried out through the cooperation of the Regional Agency for Prevention and the Environment (ARPA), as provided for in article 5.

Policy: Decree No. 470 of the Council of Ministers validating the Regulation on Kupalovsky biosphere reserve.
Policy_Content: Kupalovsky biosphere reserve shall be allotted the area of 3834 hectares and shall have as its purpose the conservation in its natural state the unique natural landscape and the population of rare and endangered plants and wildlife species recorded in the Red Book of Belarus, of rare forest cenosis, and also for the reproduction of natural environment of the objects of historical and cultural heritage. The following activities shall be prohibited on the territory of Kupalovsky biosphere reserve: 1) land reclamation and drainage causing change of the natural landscape and hydrological regime; 2) damage and annihilation of shrubbery and forest plantations and disturbance of soil; 3) burning out dry plantations and land clearing; 4) setting up tourist camps. The proclamation of Kupalovsky biosphere reserve shall not entail the expropriation of land. The regional executive bodies shall be the managing authority of Kupalovsky biosphere reserve. Land tenants must observe the regime of protected area and use ecofriendly processes. The damages caused to Kupalovsky biosphere reserve shall be compensated by the legal and natural persons in conformity with the modalities established by law.
Subject: Forestry, Wild species & ecosystems

Policy: Private Land Forest Practices Regulation (B.C. Reg. 318/99).
Policy_Content: This Regulation provides governing provisions for private land forests and is divided into 5 parts as follows: Part 1 - Definitions and Interpretation; Part 2 - Management Requirements on Identified Land; Part 3 - Remedies, Orders and Appeals; Part 4 - Audits Part 5 - Miscellaneous and Schedule A - Forest Management Objectives. This Regulation limits areas that may be occupied by unrehabilitated roads and landings and imposes requirements for timber harvesting access structures that permit soil conservation. General requirements around streams and fish habitat are laid out in detail for example: to prevent stream channels, banks and gully side walls becoming destabilized or damaged; to prevent woody debris or slash in the stream channels resulting in harm to fish or fish habitat, or damage to water supply installations; Specific Requirements for Fish Streams and Water Supply Areas are also highlighted for instance: retention of trees adjacent to large and small streams; yarding activities, site rehabilitation, and management of fertilizers near streams. Provisions on critical wildlife habitat, and reforestation are also dealt with. This Regulation goes into detail regarding the practices and procedures pertaining to the Advisory Panels, reviews appeals and offences. The miscellaneous provisions highlight confidentiality, disclosure and identified threatened or endangered fish.

Policy: Designation of Nitrate Vulnerable Zones (Scotland) Regulations 2000 (S.S.I. No. 96 of 2000).
Policy_Content: The Protection of Water Against Agricultural Nitrate Pollution (Scotland) Regulations 1996 transpose for Scotland the requirements of Council Directive 91/676/EC concerning the protection of waters against pollution caused by nitrates from agricultural sources. The objective of the Directive is to ensure that measures are taken to reduce and prevent nitrate pollution from agricultural sources. It provides a framework for action to reduce nitrate levels in the catchments of rivers and groundwater sources affected by such pollution, and to reduce eutrophication of freshwater bodies, estuaries, and coastal waters. Those Regulations designated only one nitrate vulnerable zone in Scotland. These Regulations designate the catchment and estuary of the River Ythan in Aberdeenshire as a nitrate vulnerable zone (reg. 3).and amend the 1996 Regulations in consequence of that designation and make other minor amendments, including the re-instatement of the reference to the Code of Good Practice which is necessary for the purposes of regulation 7.

Policy: Burgenland Air Pollution Control, Heating and Air Conditioning Plants Law 2008.
Policy_Content: The purpose of the present Law is the prevention of harmful changes in the natural composition of the ambient air by hazardous substances (smoke, dust, soot, gas) in the running of heating systems used in whole or in part, to heat buildings or prepare warm water. Moreover, heating systems shall be produced, and marketed and run according to the latest technical standards in such a way that they shall: 1) not endanger the life of people or their well-being; 2) not harm or negatively influence animals and plants and the natural eco system; and 3) prevent harmful effect on the environment. Part 1 deals with objectives and principles, sphere of application, general requirement for fuels and technical requirements for heating systems. Part 2 concerns bringing into circulation of small heating systems, inspection report, refusal to issue report on inspection, technical documentation and approval of inspection reports and authorization. Part 3 focuses on bringing into circulation of special heating systems, conformity proceedings, marking and authorized offices. Part 4 regards establishment, major changes and inspection of heating systems and instruction to run heating systems. Parts 5 deals with inspection of heating systems, inspection organs, entitled persons and  person under a duty, use of property and duty to give information; and Part 6 concerns competent authorities, penalties, transitional provisions, entry into force and comments on notifications. The text consists of 28 articles divided into 6 Parts.
Subject: Air & atmosphere
Keyword: Air quality/air pollution,Basic legislation,Emissions,Environmental standards,Pollution control

Policy: Renewable Energy Sources Act.
Policy_Content: The purpose of this Act is to facilitate a sustainable development of energy supply in the interest of managing global warming and protecting the environment and to achieve a substantial increase in the percentage contribution made by renewable energy sources to power supply in order at least to double the share of renewable energy sources in total energy consumption by the year 2010, in keeping with the objectives defined by the European Union and by the Federal Republic of Germany. This Act deals with the purchase of, and the compensation to be paid for, electricity generated exclusively from hydrodynamic power, wind energy, solar radiation energy, geothermal energy, gas from sanitary landfills, sewage treatment plants, mines, or biomass within the territorial scope of this Act or within Germany's exclusive economic zone, by utility companies which operate grids for public power supply (grid operators). The Federal Ministry for Environment, Nature Conservation and Nuclear Safety shall be authorised to lay down rules- in agreement with the Federal Ministry of Food, Agriculture and Forestry as well as the Federal Ministry of Economics and Technology - by adopting an ordinance, which shall be subject to approval by the German Bundestag. Said ordinance shall specify what substances and technical processes used in connection with biomass fall within the scope of application of this Act; in addition, the ordinance shall lay down the relevant environmental standards.

Policy: Law No. 5.178 providing for the Policy on Forestry of the State of Piauí.
Policy_Content: This Law, consisting of 48 articles divided into 16 Chapters, establishes the Policy on Forestry of the State of Piauí. The Specific objectives of the Forest Policy aim to: identify, implement, manage and maintain a state system of protected areas in order to protect biological communities representative of natural forest ecosystems; facilitate and promote the development and diffusion of forestry research and technologies; promote the continuous inventory of State forest coverage, in order to allow the planning and rationalization of forest activities; promote the supply of energy and non-energy forestry products through forest management, agro-forestry and planting forest species for multiple use; carry out with the Union and Municipalities inspections in the State territory and public or private areas; create programmes of environmental recovery, afforestation, reforestation, forest management and agro-silvopastoril activities; establish educational programmes, aiming at ecological awareness, regarding the need for rational use and conservation of forest heritage; facilitate and promote the conservation, protection and recovery of water, soil and biological diversity; promote the recovery of degraded and protected areas threatened with degradation; build a programme of protection to guide the prevention and control of pests, diseases and forest fires; identify and monitor relevant plant associations, with a view to their protection; implement a database gathering forestry information; keep records of producers, traders and consumers of forestry products in the State; plan, implement and guide actions to find the dynamic balance between the supply and demand of forest raw material at regional and state levels, based on the principle of the sustainable regime and multiple use; preserve biodiversity and integrity of the patrimony of the various biomes and ecosystems of the State of Piauí; etc.

Policy_Content: La susdite loi porte la réglementation relative à la réduction du bruit émis par les chemins de fer. La protection contre le bruit sera atteinte par: a. des mesures techniques destinées à limiter les émissions des véhicules ferroviaires; b. la construction d’ouvrages antibruit destinés à limiter le bruit émis par les installations ferroviaires fixes existantes (mesures antibruit); c. l’isolation acoustique des bâtiments existants. Policy: Regional Act No. 20 laying down the legislative framework in matter of land use and land preservation.
Policy_Content: The present Act provides for the protection of the territory of the Emilia Romagna Region by making rules on land use planning. Policy: Law No. 840-IQ on protected areas.
Policy_Content: Protected areas and objects are the national property and represent special ecological, scientific, cultural and aesthetic value. The present Law establishes legal basis for the organization and protection of protected areas and objects. The main principles of the organization, protection and management of protected areas are: 1) conservation of biological diversity and ecosystem; 2) purposeful use of protected areas for scientific research, culture and education; 3) recreational use; 4) international cooperation (art. 3). The Law consists of 15 Sections composed of 50 Articles. Section 1 (arts. 1-4) lays down general provisions. Section 2 (arts. 5-12) regards organization of protected areas. Section 3 (arts. 13-16) deals with management in the sphere of protected areas and objects. Section 4 (arts. 17-20) regards state natural reserves. Section 5 (arts. 21-23) regards national parks. Section 6 (arts.24-26) regards natural parks. Section 7 (arts. 27-28) regards state game reserves. Section 8 (arts. 29-30) regards natural monuments. Section 9 (arts. 31-34) regards zoological parks. Section 10 (arts. 35-38) regards botanical gardens and dendrological parks. Section 11 (arts. 39-40) regards medicinal and recreational areas and health resorts. Section 12 (arts. 41-44) regards financial and economic regulation of protected areas and objects. Section 13 (arts. 45-46) regards control over protection and use of protected areas and objects. Section 14 (arts. 47-48) establishes liability for the infringement of legislation of protected areas and objects. Section 15 (arts. 49-50) regards international cooperation.

Policy: Ministerial Decree No. 85167/820 approving a Code of Good Agricultural Practice.
Policy_Content: This Code of Good Agricultural Practice addresses issues related to the protection of waters affected by nitrate pollution deriving from agricultural sources. It is divided into four Parts as follows: the first Part (A) concerns fertilizers and aims at assisting farmers in implementing friendly practices towards the environment in a way that income by their crops may be secured and also that the environment can be protected. In particular it aims at avoiding pollution of underground and surface waters from the accumulation of nitrates through water infiltration or surface runoff. The second Part (B) aims at moderating the continuously increasing water pollution from nitrate ions by the excessive use of animal waste. The correct use of irrigation water by the farmers can considerably contribute in the reduction of nitrates concentration in underground waters. In the third Part (C), practical guidelines on the correct application of various irrigation methods are provided so that the deep infiltration of water can be limited as well as the surface runoff, factors that contribute in nitrate spread. The last Part (D) of this Code provides for an integrated pest management system, the storage, transport and use of plant protection products and the monitoring of plant diseases.

Policy: Planning (Control of Major-Accident Hazards) Regulations (Northern Ireland) 2000 (S.R. No. 101 of 2000).
Policy_Content: These Regulations are concerned with the implementation of Article 12 of Council Directive 96/82/EC on the control of major-accident hazards involving dangerous substances. The main provisions of Article 12 of the Directive are the requirement to ensure that the objectives of preventing major accidents and limiting their consequences are taken into account in land-use planning policies and that these objectives are pursued through controls. There is also a requirement to ensure that planning authorities set up appropriate consultation procedures to facilitate implementation of these and other policies established under that Article. Article 53 of the 1991 Order provides that the presence of a hazardous substance on, over or under land at or above the controlled quantity requires hazardous substances consent. The controlled quantity must be calculated by aggregating the quantity of a substance on, over or under land and certain other land or structure ). Regulation 2(1) - (3) amends Article 53 by adding to the control zone any other land which forms part of a single.
Subject: Land & soil, Waste & hazardous substances

Policy: Scotland Act 1998 (Cross-Border Public Authorities) (Forestry Commissioners) Order 2000 (S.I. No. 746 of 2000).
Policy_Content: This Order, which is made under section 89 of the Scotland Act 1998 amends statutory provisions relating to the Forestry Commissioners, who are a cross-border public authority for the purposes of that Act. The Order makes further amendments to provisions which govern the funding of forestry functions, following the abolition of the Forestry Fund on the coming into force of the 1998 Act in July 1999. Article 2 gives effect to the amendments contained in the Schedule. The principal provision is paragraph 5, which amends the Forestry Act 1967. Paragraphs 5(2) to (5) amend section 41 of the Forestry Act 1967, the provisions on funding, which was amended by the 1999 Order. Except in relation to Scotland, the expenses of the Commissioners, and forestry expenses of the Minister (the Minister of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food or the Secretary of State), are to be met out of money provided by Parliament only if they cannot be met out of receipts held by the Commissioners. The Commissioners are empowered to hold sums received to meet such expenditure, unless the Minister (with the consent of the Treasury) directs that the receipts should be paid into the Consolidated Fund. As regards Scotland, the provisions made by the 1999 Order are preserved under which the expenses of the Commissioners as regards Scotland, and the Scottish Ministers' forestry expenses, are met out of the Scottish Consolidated Fund, and their respective receipts paid into that Fund, subject to any Act of the Scottish Parliament. The Minister and the Scottish Ministers are also given power to determine by agreement questions relating to whether or not particular expenses or receipts fall within the provisions of section 41 relating to Scotland.
Subject: Forestry
Geographical_area: Atlantic Ocean Islands, Europe, EUROPE AND CENTRAL ASIA, European Union Countries, North Atlantic, North Sea, North-East Atlantic, Northern Europe

Policy: Control of Major Accident Hazards Regulations (Northern Ireland) 2000 (S.R. No. 93 of 2000).
Policy_Content: These Regulations impose requirements with respect to the control of major accident hazards involving dangerous substances. They implement Council Directive 96/82/EC on the control of major accident hazards involving dangerous substances, except Article 12 (which relates to land use planning) and apply to establishments (as defined in regulation 2(1)) where dangerous substances are present in quantities equal to or exceeding those specified in column 2 of Parts II or III of Schedule 1, except that regulations 7 to 14 apply to establishments where such substances are present in quantities equal to or exceeding those specified in column 3 of those Parts. They, among other things: (a) impose a duty on the operator of an establishment to take all measures necessary to prevent major accidents and limit their consequences for persons and the environment; (b) impose a duty on the operator to prepare a major accident prevention policy document containing specified information and to revise it in specified circumstances; (c) require the operator to notify the competent authority of specified matters at specified times; (d) require the operator to send at specified times a safety report to the competent authority containing specified information, to revise that report in specified circumstances, and not to start the construction or operation of the establishment until (s)he has received from the competent authority the conclusions of its examination of the report; (e) require the operator to review and revise the safety report in specified circumstances; (f) require the operator to prepare an on-site emergency plan for specified purposes and containing specified information.
Subject: Land & soil, Waste & hazardous substances

Policy: Ministerial Decree No. 42 on use and leasing of pastures and compensation of production losses in agriculture and forestry.
Policy_Content: This Decree states that the Regulation on compensation of production losses in agriculture and forestry shall be approved. The fees shall be collected from the real and legal persons damaging soil quality in agricultural land and forests. These collected fees shall be used for improving agricultural development. In addition, the Regulation on use and leasing of pastures shall be approved by this Decree. According to this Regulation, the cattle ranges owned by the municipalities and under the management of local executive authorities shall be used communally. The state control shall be carried out on the intended use of pastures, hayfields and cattle ranges. In case that the productivity and fertility of pastures, hayfield and cattle ranges decrease as a result of natural factors, the relevant local authorities or municipalities shall conserve these areas by withdrawing from circulation. This Regulation sets out provisions on distribution, use and leasing of winter and summer pastures, hayfields and cattle ranges. This Regulation underlines that the summer and winter pastures regardless of the ownership are the natural sources for animal feeds, therefore they are important for the increase of feed reserves in order to ensure the development of livestock.

Policy: Ministerial Decree No. 120 validating the Regulation on the state forest reserve Zorkul.
Policy_Content: The Regulation consists of 3 Sections composed of 23 issues dealing with the following matters: 1) general provisions (sect. 1, issues 1-8); 2) the main tasks of the state forest reserve (sect. 2, issue 9); 3) protection of the state forest reserve (sect. 3, issues 10-23). The state forest reserve Zorkul shall have as its purpose the conservation of rare and endangered animals and plants in their natural habitats. The state forest reserve Zorkul shall have the following tasks: 1) conservation and enrichment of flora and fauna; 2) conservation and renewal of typical natural complexes; 3) study of animals, birds and plants; 4) marking of animals and birds; 4) captive breeding of wild animals and the subsequent release thereof in the natural environment; 5) biotechnological arrangements. Economic activity, recreation and any other activity contrary to the scope of the state forest reserve Zorkul and harmful to environment shall be prohibited. Scientific research, renewal and forest fire prevention activity must not be contrary to the scope of the state forest reserve.

Policy: Land Title Act 2000.

It consists of 220 sections and is divided into 14 Parts and completed by two Schedules. Under Part 2, the Registrar-General is required to keep a land register and has the power to hold inquiries and to demand fees. Part 3 is dedicated to the operation of the land registrar, Part 4 to the registration of lands, Part 5 to joint holders and Part 6 to transfer, leases, mortgages, easements and trusts. Policy: Environmental Impact Assessment (Forestry) Regulations (Northern Ireland) 2000 (S.R. No. 84 of 2000).
Policy_Content: Regulation 2 defines terms used in the Regulations. The Regulations continue a prohibition on carrying out any work or operations in relation to a project which is a "relevant project" unless consent has been obtained from the Department of Agriculture and Rural Development. A further new provision gives the Department power, in accordance with Directive 85/337/EC, as amended, to exempt particular projects from the application of the Regulations (reg. 4). "Relevant project" is defined in regulation 3 as one of four types of project relating to forestry which does not constitute development regulated by the legislation on town and country planning but which is likely to have substantial effects on the environment. A person who proposes to carry out a project may apply to the Department for an opinion as to whether the project is a relevant project. In determining that issue account must be taken of the environmental criteria set out in Schedule 3. The proposer of a project may also seek an opinion from the Department as to the information that should be included in the environmental statement attached to an application for consent (reg. 9). Applications to the Department for consent for a relevant project must be accompanied by an environmental statement which must contain the information required by Schedule 1 to the Regulations. Where it appears that the project may be likely to have significant effects on the environment in another State of the European Economic Area, provision is made for the authorities of that State to be consulted before a decision is made. In making its decision the Department is required to have regard to the environmental statement and the direct and indirect effects on environmental factors specified in Schedule 4. The Department is given powers to serve enforcement notices where relevant projects are carried out without consent or in breach of conditions. The person served with such a notice may request the Department to review an enforcement notice. Penalties are specified for breach of an enforcement notice. A power of entry and certain default powers are conferred on officers authorized by the Department (regs. 19 to 22). The Department is required to keep a register of directions, opinions, and determinations for public inspection (reg. 23).
Subject: Environment gen., Forestry

Policy_Content: This Government Decree regulates the Farmer Loan Facility and the Farmer Loan Programme. In order to reduce the indebtedness of agricultural producers, to create the financial conditions for the desired farming and production structure, a credit facility will be launched under the conditions set out in this Regulation. Section 2 of the 273/1997 on the general conditions for the use of agricultural subsidies in the development loan scheme. Applicants must have: (a) 50% of its annual turnover coming from agricultural activity. Applicants may take part in the development loan scheme on the basis of a detailed application issued by the Ministry responsible for agricultural policy (hereinafter referred to as the Ministry). The application must include: (a) development plan; (b) amount, distribution and loan amount of the loan to be converted on 31 December 1999 per credit agreement; (c) the amount of additional credit needed to realize the development plan; (d) certificate from the county government office acting within the scope of its competence in the field of agriculture as provided for in Article 2 (a) and (b). The development plan shall include: (a) specific information to the current situation of the enterprise (production structure, assets, ownership structure, profitability, liabilities, etc.); (b) a program to change the production structure; (c) impact on the asset situation or on additional capital resources of the activities to be eliminated or reduced; (d) information on the impact of production change on product quality, information on the market position of products; (e) planned change in profitability; (f) impact on employment; (g) associated liquidity plan, the additional source of funds, etc.

Policy: Regional Law No. 5-OZ “On seed growing, selection and selection achievements”.
Policy_Content: This Law regulates legal relationship between producers and consumers of seeds on the basis of optimal combination of the interest of seed growers and the state. It deals with the issues of seed production, procurement, processing, storage, transportation, trade and utilization of seeds of agricultural crops. It shall be applicable to seeds inserted in the State Register of Selection. Agricultural seeds shall be classified as follows: (a) original; (b) elite; and (c) reproduction. Forest seeds shall be classified as follows: (a) normal; (b) improved; and (c) variety. Only seeds complying with state standards and variety requirements shall be authorized for seed production. State support to seed growing of agricultural crops shall be granted in the form of preferential tax application, compensation of part of expenditure for seed growing and subsidies.

Policy: Regional Law No. 82-KZ “On ensuring fertility of agricultural land”.
Policy_Content: The scope of this Regional Law shall be to ensure fertility of agricultural land by owners, landlords, land tenants and leaseholders. The main arrangements for ensuring soil fertility shall be: (a) elaboration and realization of regional programs; (b) soil, agrochemical, phytosanitary, ecological and toxicological inspection; (c) investments in soil conservation and reproduction; and (d) improvement of soil quality and fertility. Owners, tenants and leaseholders of agricultural land must: (a) prevent soil pollution, littering and degradation; (b) carry out agricultural production by methods ensuring reproduction of soil fertility and preventing negative environmental impact; (c) inform authorized institutions of soil pollution and degradation of agricultural land; and (d) not apply ecologically hazardous fertilizers, ameliorators and pesticides. Possessors, owners, users, including tenants, of land plots shall have the right to perform agro-technical, agrochemical, land reclamation, phytosanitary and anti-erosion reproductive measures for restoration of agricultural land fertility; receive information from executive bodies of the regional authorities in accordance with the established procedure related to the state of soil fertility on their land and the dynamics of its condition.

El FONDEN es, por lo tanto, un complemento de las acciones que deben de llevarse a cabo para la prevención de desastres naturales. Es por ello que, de forma independiente a la existencia y operación del mismo, resulta indispensable que las dependencias y entidades federales, así como las entidades federativas, fortalezcan las medidas de seguridad y de prevención necesarias que ayuden a afrontar de mejor manera los efectos que ocasiona un desastre natural, incluyendo las acciones que permitan dar aviso oportuno y masivo a la población.

Policy: Law on Forests (2000)
Policy_Content: This Law regulates forestry. Its purpose is to promote economically, ecologically, and socially sustainable management and use of the forest by ensuring equal rights, inviolability of the ownership rights, and independence of economic activity of all owners or lawful possessors of the forest, and determining equal obligations; and to govern the conditions for the management and alienation of the State forest land. The Law provides that forest management may not be in contradiction with the requirements specified in the spatial development planning documents. The Law applies to persons for which forest land is in the ownership or lawful possession; and persons whose rights are determined and obligations imposed by this Law and other laws and regulations governing forest management and utilisation. The Law further provides for right of access to a forest; tree felling; utilisation of forest non-wood values; forest reproductive material; forest regeneration and afforestation; forest protection; information regarding forests, and a forest management plan; protection of nature in a forest; parks and forest parks; deforestation; forest administration by the state; scientific research forests; and liability for violations of the laws and regulations regarding forest management and utilisation.

Policy: Great Barrier Reef Marine Park (Aquaculture) Regulations 2000.
Policy_Content: These Regulations concern aquaculture in the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park. Section 66 of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act allows the Governor-General to make Regulations, including Regulations regulating or prohibiting acts, in the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park or elsewhere, that may pollute water in a manner harmful to animals and plants in the Marine Park. Aquaculture is the cultivation of aquatic animals under controlled conditions in a tank or enclosure. Aquaculture, unless properly regulated, is capable of causing significant water pollution both at the place of discharge and for some distance downstream. Regulation 9 makes it an offence to discharge aquaculture waste into "controlled areas" as defined in regulation 9. Regulation 9 is not taken to prohibit the discharge of waste from an aquaculture facility if the discharge is in accordance with a permission given by the Authority under Part 4. In addition, aquaculture may be carried on as authorized by a Queensland law that has been accredited by the Minister. Smaller aquaculture operations either are exempt or their operators are obliged to report periodically to the Authority. The rest of these Regulations set out laws in relation to applications to the Authority for permission to discharge aquaculture waste and make provision for enforcing the Regulations and the conditions of permissions. (62 regulations divided into 8 Parts)

Policy: Law No. 1492 III “On apiculture”.
Policy_Content: This Law regulates relations concerning apiculture, keeping honey bees, production, processing of apiculture products, use of honey bees for pollination of agricultural entomophilous plant and crops, ensuring protection of rights and legal interests of natural and legal persons performing apiculture. It shall be applicable to pedigree and common commercial apiaries. State support of apiculture shall be carried out by means of: (a) promotion of apiculture, research and conservation of bee genetic resources; (b) compensation of veterinary and sanitary servicing of apiculture; (c) application of preferential taxation to bee farmers; and (d) allocation of credits and subsidies (Art. 8). Apiculture shall be performed without issuance of any particular authorization (Art. 11). The number of bee families that can be owned by natural  and legal persons shall not be limited (Art. 12). Apiaries shall be subject to compulsory registration and issuance of sanitary and veterinary certificate (Art. 13). Natural and legal persons can put apiaries on plots of land pertaining to their ownership or tenancy (Art. 15). Apiculture products shall be subject to compulsory veterinary and sanitary expertise prior trade and vending thereof (Arts. 18-19).

Policy: Règlement grand-ducal concernant la teneur en soufre de certains combustibles liquides.
Policy_Content: Le susdit règlement porte des dispositions relatives à la teneur en souffre de certains combustibles liquides. L’article 1er établit que le même règlement a pour objet de réduire les émissions de dioxyde de soufre résultant de la combustion de certains types de combustibles liquides et de diminuer ainsi les effets néfastes de ces émissions sur l’homme et l’environnement. En outre, pour diminuer les émissions de dioxyde de soufre résultant de la combustion de certains combustibles liquides dérivés du pétrole, l’utilisation de ces combustibles sur le territoire luxembourgeois est subordonnée au respect d’une teneur maximale en soufre. Le texte comprend 8 articles dont les plus importants sont: Objectifs et champ d’application (art 1er); Teneur maximale en soufre des fiouls lourds (art. 3);.Teneur maximale en soufre du gas-oil (art. 4); Surveillance de la teneur en soufre (art. 5); Dispositions abrogatoires (art. 6); Entrée en vigueur (art. 7); Exécution (art. 8).
Subject: Air & atmosphere

Policy: Regional Act No. 11 on the collection, the improvement and the marketing of spontaneous fresh and conserved mushrooms.
Policy_Content: This Act regulates the collection and the marketing of mushrooms. The collection of mushrooms is allowed in woods and on non cultivated land upon the issuing of an authorization. The authorization is personal, renewable and valid within the Region. The collection is authorized all week long, but each person may not collect more than 3 Kilos of mushrooms per day with the exception of mushrooms that weight alone three kilos. Professional collectors may collect mushrooms in specific areas and without the quantity and time limit. Associations and cooperatives may obtain a special permit for the collection of mushrooms. Only authorized people may market mushrooms and the shall have a sanitary label and respect the national provisions on labelling. (27 Articles)

Policy: Instructions No. 56 of the Ministry of Taxes and Dues regarding the application of the Law on land charges.
Policy_Content: Land tenure in the Russian Federation is requiring payment. Land charges include land tax, rent and normative land value. Landowners, landlords and land tenants, except for leaseholders, are liable to annual land tax. Land transferred on condition of lease is charged with rent. Normative land value is fixed for the purpose of purchase and redemption of the plots of land in cases envisaged by the Russian Legislation as well as for hypothecating the plots of land. The purpose of the introduction of land charges is to stimulate the rational use, protection and development of land, increase of soil fertility, levelling of social and economic conditions of management of the plots of land of different quality, providing for the development of infrastructure of populated areas and setting up special funds for the financing of the above-mentioned arrangements. The rate of land charge doesn't depend on the results of economic activity of landowners, landlords and land tenants and is fixed as the form of stable annual payment for a unit of land area. The document consists of V Sections that contain 50 paragraphs. Section I classifies the categories of land tax payers and the objects of taxation. Section II regards favourable terms for paying land charges and the modalities of their concession. Section III determines the modalities of calculation and payment of land charges. Section IV regards the modalities of entering in an account, centralisation and use of land charges revenues. Section V deals with normative land value.
Subject: Land & soil

Policy: Ministerial Decree No.260 of 2000 regarding the sphere of competence of the Committee of Environmental Protection subordinated to the Ministry of Natural Resources and Environmental Protection.
Policy_Content: The Premier decrees to validate the Regulation on the statute of the Committee. The Committee is an institution within the sphere of competence of the Ministry entitled with the task of carrying out special executive, control and survey functions in the sphere of environmental protection. The main functions of the Committee are: 1. ensuring environmental protection and rational use of natural resources; 2. organization of state environmental monitoring; 3. organization of state ecological audit; 4. realization of common state policy in the sphere of environmental protection and organization of carrying out state and other programs in the afore-mentioned sphere. He document consists of 5 sections. Section 1 lays down general provisions. Section 2 establishes targets, functions and plenary powers of the Committee. Section 3 regards property of the Committee. Section 4 regards organization of activity of the Committee. Section 5 regards reorganization and liquidation of the Committee.

Policy: Land Registration Rules 2000 (S.I. No. 429 of 2000).
Policy_Content: These rules: (A) amend the Land Registration Rules 1925 so as to provide a framework for notification of discharge of a registered charge by electronic means where the Registrar is satisfied that adequate arrangements have been made for their delivery and he has issued a notice to that effect; (B) amend the Land Registration (Open Register) Rules 1991 so as to introduce an enquiry service to establish if notification of discharge of a registered charge has been received by electronic means where the Registrar is satisfied that adequate arrangements have been made for their delivery and he has issued a notice to that effect; (C) substitute a new form in the Land Registration (Matrimonial Home Rights) Rules 1997 and remove the requirement to lodge the form in duplicate.

Policy: Decree of the Minister of Natural Resources No. 208 of 2000 relative timber destined to be placed on the market.
Policy_Content: This Decree distinguishes between marketable timber species (listed as category A in the Schedule), potentially marketable timber species (all species other than categories A and C, and timber species the logging of which is prohibited (listed as category C in the Schedule) (art. 2). Article 3 gives a definition of “marketable species” and describes size and other characteristics of such timber. No logging shall take place of marketable timber or potentially marketable timber trees of less than 35 centimetres of diameter. Felling of prohibited species requires a special exemption from the Chief of National Forestry Management (art. 5). The provisions of this Decree shall not apply to one-time exploitation forest or forests to be rejuvenated.
Subject: Forestry

Policy: Decree of the Minister of Natural Resources No. 207/9961 of 2000 relative to the transportation of forestry products.
Policy_Content: This Decree contains directions for the transportation of forest products, in implementation of section 45, second comma of the Forestry Management Act 1992. The directions, contained in the Schedule, concern timber, charcoal, fuelwood, leaves, seeds and beans. Articles 3, 5 and 6 provide for various matters regarding transport documents. No products may be transported between 7 p.m. and 6.30 a.m. of each day. The Chief of National Forestry Management may give issue further directions regarding transportation of forestry products. Transporters are required to report to forest guard posts when passing. A register of transport documents shall be kept by the Chief of National Forestry Management.

Policy: Decree of the Minister of Natural Resources No. 209 of 2000 relative statistical production data.
Policy_Content: Each registered transporter of forestry products and operator of a wood processing activity as mentioned in sections 46 and 47 of the Forestry Management Act 1992 shall be required to submit, at the request of the Chief of National Forestry Management, all relevant information as specified in article 3. This information regards type and quantity of forestry products processed, type and quantity of products obtained from processing, international and local market prices, processing capacity and staff. Transporters shall submit information at least once a year, whereas operators shall do so each trimester. Non fulfilment of obligations under this Decree may bring about revocation of permit. (6 articles)

Policy: Decree of the Minister of Natural Resources No. 214 of 2000 implementing comma 3 of section 17 of the Forestry Management Act 1992 relative to transfer of an exploration permit and concession.
Policy_Content: This Decree establishes criteria for the approval of transfer of exploration permit in the sense of section 23 or a concession in the sense of section 25 of the Forestry Management Act 1992. Sections 17, 21 and 29 of the Act shall be observed. Article 3 concerns the procedure of application for transfer of a concession or permit. Approval shall be granted by the competent authority (not defined). Article 5 defines the grounds on which an application shall be rejected. The new concession holder or holder of a permit shall continue the concession or exploration at the same terms and for the same period as its predecessor. An adjustment in the operational plan may be required by the competent authority.

Policy: Decree of the Minister of Natural Resources No. 211 of 2000 establishing criteria for the granting of a permit for occasional timber logging.
Policy_Content: This Decree lays down rules for occasional timber logging in one-time exploitation forests in the sense of the Forestry Management Act 1992. The holder of permit for occasional felling shall be subject to the same rules that apply to holders of concessions, being specified in the Act. An occasional felling permits shall be issued only once in the same year to the same person and shall be valid for maximum one year in specified areas only. A logging register shall be kept by the holder of a permit. Other provisions of this Decree deal with application for a permit.

The applicant shall fill out the form contained in the Schedule to this Decree and submit information specified in article 4. This information includes information regarding the financial capacity of the applicant, an overview of concessions or permits already in possession of the applicant, an inventory of equipment to be used for logging, etc, and a specification of technical capacity of the applicant.
